item.gloss: Plush: 'A rich fabric of silk, cotton, wool, or other material (or any of these combined), with a long soft nap', OEDO.
Dial: 'A sundial or similar instrument which indicates the time of day by means of the shadow of a pointer cast by the sun on to a marked surface', OEDO.
Fair copy: 'A neat, clearly legible copy of a written … document; spec. a transcript free from corrections', OEDO.
Dial: 'A sundial or similar instrument which indicates the time of day by means of the shadow of a pointer cast by the sun on to a marked surface', OEDO.
Nonage: 'The state of being under full legal age; minority', OEDO. In Quarles, this reads ‘nonag’d’. Francis Quarles, Emblemes (London: Printed for Francis Eglesfeild, 1639), 178.
Ungirt: 'Not girded or wearing a girdle', OEDO.
Temporal: ‘Secular as opposed to sacred,’ OEDO.

Widows-cruse: '(With allusion to 1 Kings 17:12–16) a cruse or small vessel containing oil which seems to never run out, belonging to a poor widow; an apparently small or meagre supply which seems to be inexhaustible', OEDO.
Closet: ‘A space devoted to private study or speculative thought’, OEDO.

Providence: ‘The foreknowing and protective care of God (or nature, etc.); divine direction, control, or guidance’, OEDO. See Alexandra Walsham, Providence in Early Modern England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1999).

Witness: A godparent usually associated with the puritan tradition, which saw the role of godparents as being quite restricted. While Thomas Comber used the term interchangeably with others, including ‘godparent’, in his Brief Discourse Upon the Offices of Baptism and Confirmation (1675), Thornton changed her vocabulary from the 1650s to the 1660s. See David Cressy, Birth, Marriage and Death: Ritual, Religion, and the Life-Cycle in Tudor and Stuart England (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1997), 152.
